metadata.title: Summarizing Harry Potter With ML. The magic of Speech-To-Text and NLP | by Sagi Shaier | Medium

all_paragraphs: Have you ever wished there was an easy way to get a summary of a really long, and even possibly boring video? This can be a movie that you are forced to watch for class, a speech made by someone important, or even just an audio recording of your pet. In this article you will learn exactly how to do that.

In this project I explored some more fascinating areas of machine learning and applied them to two different videos (Harry Potter, and The Boarded Window).The project is avaiable on my GitHub as usual.

Starting with a movie/audio.mp3, I first converted the file to .wav extension to improve the quality of the file. There are many resources to do it online and I believe you can also do it in Python (I did it online just because it was faster).
Next, I tried several speech-to-text engines to see which one will provide the best accuracy.The first one I tried was Pocketsphinx, which is completely free and fairly easy to use:

However, the accuracy for several videos was quite terrible and so I went on and looked for another recognition engine. Consider trying Sphinx first (since it’s a lot easier to use than other engines) with your project and see if the accuracy is in fact bad.

Next, I wanted to try Google Cloud Speech-to-Text since there are lot of good reviews on it. Apparently you also get $300 to spend on Google Cloud Platform over the next 12 months if you sign up. However, Google asks for a credit card number in order to register. At this point I started looking for another program (I didn’t want to give my credit card info). Note, Google Cloud suppose to be one of the best engines to convert speech to text. If you’re willing to give up your info you should definitely consider using it.

Lastly, I found IBM’s Watson- a highly accurate speech engine which easily converts audio and voice into written text for quick understanding of content. IBM registration was surprisingly easy.Once you register up you can use Watson.
Using Watson in Python is quite complex at first, but once you know what to do it’s easy (like most things). I tried to make it simple to follow:
